intro: Paepalanthus stenolepis, commonly known as the narrow-leaved puya, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly Argentina and Chile. It belongs to the family Xanthorrhoeaceae and is characterized by its rosette-forming leaves and striking inflorescences. The plant produces showy, spike-like flower clusters that are often brightly colored, attracting pollinators such as bees and birds. It is adapted to arid environments and has a slow growth rate, making it a long-lived species. Its unique morphology and ecological role make it an important subject in botanical studies.
